title: Karioka Sweet Rice Balls Recipe
description: Karioka, deep-fried coconut rice balls, are a traditional sweet Filipino dessert that are very quick and easy to prepare.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Global Cuisines Asian Filipino Karioka Sweet Rice Balls 3.8 (6) 2 Reviews 4 Photos A Filipino family-favorite! These go fast at family gatherings. Can be served on skewers to prevent sticky fingers! Submitted by mystinkypete Updated on August 11, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 4 4 Prep Time: 10 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Additional Time: 10 mins Total Time: 30 mins Servings: 5 Yield: 5 rice balls Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 5 servings 1 cup rice flour 1 cup shredded coconut ¾ cup coconut milk 2 cups vegetable oil for frying Coating: ½ cup coconut milk ¼ cup brown sugar Directions Mix rice flour, shredded coconut, and 3/4 cup coconut milk together in a bowl until dough is well mixed. Form dough into balls, about 1 tablespoon per ball. Heat oil in a pot over medium heat. Fry dough balls in the hot oil until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Remove pot from heat and transfer balls to a paper towel-lined plate. Pour 1/2 cup coconut milk into a saucepan; bring to a boil. Stir brown sugar into hot coconut milk until liquid thickens, 2 to 3 minutes more. Remove saucepan from heat, cool coconut coating slightly, and dip balls into coating. Cool slightly before serving. From the Editor We have determined the nutritional value of oil for frying based on a retention value of 10% after cooking. The exact amount will vary depending on cooking time and temperature, ingredient density, and the specific type of oil used. name: mystinkypete
instructions: Mix rice flour, shredded coconut, and 3/4 cup coconut milk together in a bowl until dough is well mixed. Form dough into balls, about 1 tablespoon per ball.;Heat oil in a pot over medium heat.;Fry dough balls in the hot oil until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Remove pot from heat and transfer balls to a paper towel-lined plate.;Pour 1/2 cup coconut milk into a saucepan; bring to a boil. Stir brown sugar into hot coconut milk until liquid thickens, 2 to 3 minutes more. Remove saucepan from heat, cool coconut coating slightly, and dip balls into coating. Cool slightly before serving.
